newsitem.title: USA: BARRA, Prebon to launch FRA trade system.
newsitem.headline: BARRA, Prebon to launch FRA trade system.

text.p: BARRA Inc and Prebon Yamane (USA) Inc plan to launch the first computer-based system for crossing forward rate agreements, the two firms said in a news release on Thursday.

The system, POSIT-FRA, will allow financial institutions to match specific sets of forward rate agreement (FRA) contracts to offset interest rate rest risk, which occurs daily in interest rate swap portfolios.

BARRA, the Berkeley, Calif.-based provider of money management and consulting services, developed POSIT, an electronic trade matching system for equities, with Investment Technology Group Inc in 1987.

POSIT-FRA is expected to be launched in the next several months, Harry Fry, Prebon's deputy managing director, said in an interview. "We are still working on talking with our customers and getting feedback," Fry said.
BARRA is also in final negotiations with Investment Technology to license the POSIT technology to BARRA and Prebon's POSIT-FRA, a BARRA spokesperson said.
"We are excited about the opportunity to adapt the POSIT technology to a fixed income environment," Kamal Duggirala, president of BARRA Inc, said in a news release.

POSIT-FRA, which is designed to handle transactions in a variety of currencies and may be extended to other markets in the future, will initially run one crossing session each day after Eurodollar futures close at 1400 CST/2000 GMT.
POSIT stands for Portfolio Systems for Institutional Trading, the spokesperson said.

Prebon Yamane, based in Jersey City, New Jersey, provides brokerage services for institutions in money markets and a wide variety of derivatives markets. ((Derivatives desk 312-408-8750;E-mail derivatives@reuters.com))
